fields.description:
h3. Summary
When using the *AND* operator in the JQL query for the same field twice, the board goes missing from the project overview page. 

h3. Environment
# Tested in JIRA 6.4.12 & JIRA 7.1.9

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Scrum Project ( SCRUM )
# Create a second board from an existing project ( same project as step one )
# Create 2 components in the project ( A, B )
# Create 3 issues
## First issue with component = A
## Second issue with component = B
## Third issue with component = A , B 
# Create 2 Filters
# First filter - using bracket operator for component
{code}
Project = SCRUM AND issuetype = Story AND component in (A, B)
{code}
# Second Filter - using AND operator for component
{code}
project = SCRUM AND issuetype = Story AND component = A AND component = B
{code}
# Go to the Project Overview Page, and noticed that there are 2 boards visible ( SCRUM board & SCRUM board 2 )
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 
# Change the saved filter of SCRUM board 2 to use the Second Filter - using AND operator for component
 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 
# Refresh the project overview page

h3. Expected Results
Both boards should be still visible on the project overview page

h3. Actual Results
SCRUM board 2 goes missing, Only the 1st board is displayed. 
 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes
If we changed Saved Filter of the board back to use  :
{code}
Project = SCRUM AND issuetype = Story AND component in (A, B)
{code}
The board is visible again. However, the requirement is to use {{component = A AND component = B}} as we need to return issues with have both components, not either one.
fields.summary: Board does not display on project overview page when AND operator is used in the board's saved filter

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When creating new issues in a backlog of a project, new issues are automatically ranked based on the currently highlighted issue.


h3. Environment
Cloud / Server


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new project
# Start adding tickets
# Continue to add tickets
# Select an issue in the middle of the list
# Continue to add tickets


h3. Expected Results
New tickets should be created at the bottom of the backlog unless otherwise specified in project settings


h3. Actual Results
Tickets will be ranked below highlighted ticket

 
h3. Notes
This appears to only happen whenever the backlog is log enough to scroll off the page


h3.Workaround
Ensure you always have the last issue highlighted when creating issues
fields.summary: Allow the configuration of how new tickets are ranked in the backlog

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Setting the epic link field to null or a specific value causes the failure. The issue affect both remove and add issue (during the issue creation) to the Epic via the REST API.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Run REST call, eg:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
curl -v -uuser:pass -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"fields":{"summary":"test","issuetype":{"id":"1"},"project":{"id":"10300","key":"AG"},"customfield_10401":"AG-3" }}' http://127.0.0.1:8080/rest/api/latest/issue
{code}
note, call with payload without _EpicLink_ (customfield_10401) is fine:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
'{"fields":{"summary":"test","issuetype":{"id":"1"},"project":{"id":"10300","key":"AG"} }}'
{code}

h3. Expected Results
Works fine

h3. Actual Results
{noformat}
.../rest/api/latest/issue?
Request type: POST
Content type: application/json
Post data: {"fields":{"summary":"xxx","issuetype":{"id":"1"},"customfield_11261":"XXX-123","project":{"id":"51125","key":null}}}
Response code: 500, message: Internal Server 
{"errorMessages":["Internal server error"],"errors":{}}
{noformat}

Exception in logs:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
2016-08-16 18:18:42,000 http-bio-8080-exec-11 ERROR admin 1098x560x1 4v7btn 127.0.0.1 /rest/api/latest/issue [jira.rest.exception.ExceptionInterceptor] Returning internal server error in response
java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
...
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
        at com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.issuelink.EpicServiceImpl.addIssuesToEpic(EpicServiceImpl.java:86)
        at com.atlassian.greenhopper.customfield.epiclink.EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.update(EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.java:104)
        at com.atlassian.greenhopper.customfield.epiclink.EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.handleOperation(EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.java:76)
        at com.atlassian.greenhopper.customfield.epiclink.EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.updateIssueInputParameters(EpicLinkRestFieldOperationsHandler.java:64)
        at com.atlassian.jira.rest.v2.issue.IssueInputParametersAssembler$IssueInputParametersBuilder.finalizeIssueInputParams(IssueInputParametersAssembler.java:470)
...
{code}

h3. Notes
Looks like a regression caused by JSW-10333. Works ok on JIRA Agile 6.7.12.

Fixed in JIRA 7.1.4 - see https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSW-13407
fields.summary: Creating issue with epic link field through REST causes 500 Internal Error

There is no workaround

fields.description:
The scrum master, business analysts, and product owners prioritize and groom the backlog based on our team's anticipated velocity. In other words, they really focus on the stories that are going to make the cut. Unfortunately, there's no visual indicator of where that cut will be in the backlog view in Jira.

Today, we have to manually calculate where that line would be, or we have to open up a new sprint (using the simultaneous sprint feature).

Here are a few suggestions:
 # Display a line or highlighting/shading in the backlog between the Jira issues that would make the next sprint based on previous velocity
 # Display the total story points when you select multiple issues
 # Have an option to automatically select the top issues from your backlog based on previous velocity
fields.summary: As a scrum master, I would like a way to visualize what will be included in the next sprint in the backlog view so that I do not have to manually add story points

fields.description:
Hi Jira devs,

I'm using your products on daily basis and find Zephyr+Jira integration extremely useful. I'm using ZAPI to report tests results from CI system back to Zephyr. On top of that, I'm displaying the results in Jira dashboard using "Test Execution" gadget (https://zephyrdocs.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=589892#TestMetrics(Gadgets)-test_execution). 

A feature that I'd really want to be in this gadget is the option to display test cycles based on their names (simple filtering). This is extremely needed when I want to run different test suites - showing their results on a single chart is very confusing, regarding different number of test cases and so on. If I could show, for example, test executions, grouped by Cycle, filter by cycle name "acceptance" in one chart, filter by cycle name "integration" in second chart - that would be awesome. The X axis would then show how test cycles of suites of same type were changing over time (new test cycles are always appended to the right).

Looking forward to your opinion.

Thanks!
fields.summary: "Test Executions" gadget is lacking filtering functionality

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, in JIRA the board owners are owners of the board filter. If the JIRA Admin would like to have ownership of the board, they will have to edit the filter to gain ownership.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow JIRA to assign the board ownership to JIRA Administrator.

h3. Workaround 

If the JIRA Administrator would like to change the board owner, they can do so by following workaround:

# Agile -> Manage Boards -> All Boards -> find the board 
# Click on the three dots next to it, choose "Configure".
# On the "Configure (Board)" page, note the exact name of the "Saved Filter".
# type gg, then shared. JIRA should offer "Shared Filters".
# find the filter whose name you noted in step 3
# Click the cog wheel to the right and choose "Change owner".
# Set the new owner for the shared filter. This will automatically also change the ownership of the board.
fields.summary: Assign Board Ownership to JIRA Administrator

fields.description:
It would be really nice if we could view the subtask list of an Issue on the Issue Detail section of the JIRA Board even if that type is filtered out.

Currently, The Board filter is setup in such a way where things are all or nothing. So, if I want to setup a filter to only show a parent story, I create a filter for standard Issue types. 

This is great because it keep my team focused on the parent story and I am not searching around all of the subtasks. However, if there is a parent story I need to see more detail on, I now need to click into the detail screen because if I want to see it on the Issue Detail view, its blocked by the filter.

All in all, I feel this drives a cleaner more focused board, and allows us to get a good sense of any issues without having the leave the board screen.

thanks!

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In JIRA 7.0.x+, if you attempt to delete a user with a full email address as a username and that user has issues associated, when you click on the Assigned Issue link JQL will throw an error that the @ is a reserved JQL character. This forces the end user to escape the character or put quotes around the user name.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Install JIRA 7.1.0
2. Create a user with a full email address as a username, e.g. user@host.com
3. Assign that user an issue
4. Attempt to delete the issue
5. Click on the Assigned Issue link in the pop up box that states "Cannot delete user. user@host.com has associations in JIRA that cannot be removed automatically"

h3. Expected Results
JIRA will find the users issues and not throw an error
Actual Results
JQL throws an error stating the @ sign is a reserved keyword
h3. Notes
I tested with 6.4.13 as well and this behavior does not occur
h3. Workaround
Add quotations around the user name
fields.summary: JQL throws a reserved JQL character error when searching for users with full email address

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The 'Multiple user picker' field in JIRA allows to enter deactivated users. They don't appear in the dropdown, but you can just type the name and it will be saved. In other 'user picker' fields, you won't be allowed to save after you enter a user that is not active.

h3. Environment
(Optional - If Applicable)
* 
* 

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Go to the *User Management* section and copy the username of any deactivated user. 
# In JIRA, go to a Service Desk project and click the *Create* button (It's easier to reproduce in Service Desk because it includes by default a 'multiple user picker')
# In the *Approvers* field, paste the username of the deactivated user. Nothing will show up in the dropdown, but the field won't complain. (This field is a 'multiple user picker' as you can see at *Cog icon > Issues > Custom fields*).
# After you click *Save*, that deactivated user will be accepted.

Note: if you have an existing project in SD, you can also reproduce it by clicking *Edit* on the top left corner and adding the username in the *Approvers* field.

h3. Expected Results
If the user you type is not in the dropdown menu, you'll see an error after you click *Save* and you won't be able to actually save it until you enter a valid username.

h3. Actual Results
You can enter any deactivated username and be able to save the issue correctly.
 
h3. Notes
This happens for any 'multiple user picker' in JIRA, not only in the *Approvers* field in Service Desk.
fields.summary: 'Multiple user picker' allows to enter deactivated users

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When displaying a JIRA board view (e.g., Backlog or Active Sprints), I see two refreshes: an AJAX refresh of the data on screen and a refresh of the page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Generate a [HAR file|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/Generating+HAR+files+and+Analysing+Web+Requests] while accessing the following URL: 
{noformat}
<Base_URL>/secure/RapidStart.jspa
{noformat}
# Analyse the HAR file using any HAR file viewer. (for example: [Google HAR Analyzer|https://toolbox.googleapps.com/apps/har_analyzer/])

h3. Expected Results
No request with rapidViewId set to “undefined”.

h3. Actual Results

fields.description:
If my board filter uses the syntax "project in (PRJ1, PRJ2)", the board is listed in the JIRA 6.4 sidebar under the "Boards in this project" drop-down list.

If my filter instead uses the syntax "category = Myprojects", the boards are not visible.
If I use a sub-filter "project in (PRJ1, PRJ2)" and reference it using "filter = 12345 and..." it doesn't show up in the list either.

I don't see any good workaround, because when you have *dozens* of filters all based on the same "project group", having to manually change them one by one to modify the project list is just not usable.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Deleting a JIRA Software project will not delete the existing rank values in the *AO_60DB71_LEXORANK* table

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a JIRA Software project and create several issues.
# A row will be added to the *AO_60DB71_LEXORANK* table for each rank field for every issue created. 
For instance, creating 10 issues in an instance with 2 LexoRank fields will create 20 rows in that table.
# Delete the project.

h3. Expected Results
The rows with the rank values for the deleted issues are deleted from the *AO_60DB71_LEXORANK* table.

h3. Actual Results
The rank values for the deleted issues remain in the *AO_60DB71_LEXORANK* table.
 
h3.Workaround
Trigger the LexoRank rebalance operation on the [LexoRank Management|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/LexoRank+Management] screen.
{panel:title=(!) Warning|borderStyle=solid| borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
A [rebalance operation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/LexoRank+Management] will purge the invalid rows from the table, but may also cause *performance problems* and take days to complete, due to the bug below:
* [JSW-11491|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSW-11491]
{panel}
fields.summary: Deleting a project does not remove the LexoRank values from the deleted issues in the database

There is a caveat that is given for any Workflow Trigger that is setup in JIRA:

_Caveats: Conditions, validators, and permissions will be ignored for automatic transitions but operate as usual for manual transitions._

For an Automatic Transition, according to the instructions, any Conditions,etc. set on Triggers will be ignored. This can sometimes be a problem, especially when a Condition is desired, since operations can occur (such as issue reopens), that are unwanted.

fields.description:
h3. Currently:
Current JIRA integration with Bitbucket (and I expect GitHub and/or other DVCSs) allows automatic linking of a JIRA issue with a git branch, provided the issue's key is included in the branch name. Commits are similarly linked if the commit message also includes the issue key, and the Development panel when viewing that issue provides direct links to those branches and/or commits. 

h3. Suggested:
As a user I would like to be able to *manually* link *one or more* arbitrarily-named branches (i.e. the branch does not need to have the issue key in its name) to an issue. This could occur in a way similar to linking JIRA issues, or an approach like Labels or Components.

h3. Example Use Case:
I tend to name branches with the issue key of an Epic or other large-effort issue. The related work may involve multiple JIRA issues, each of which should be linked to the branch. The reverse is also true -- a given Epic or other issue may pertain to (or at least have relevant information regarding) multiple branches, but those branches don't necessarily have _every_ related issue's key in their branch names.

As a workaround, I'm currently using a Custom Field to specify related branches on an issue, specifically a Labels field to try to minimize text discrepancies like typos. Duplicate values still do occur, however, since labels are case-sensitive (e.g. branch names "myfeature-KEY-123" and "myfeature-key-123" and "MyFeature-Key-123" are treated as distinct values). Possibly a drop-down selection (e.g. similar to Project Components) could be available for this field so that links are made to a pre-determined list of known existing branches, or some happy medium.
fields.summary: Ability to manually link an issue with multiple development branches

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Users can connect JIRA to Bitbucket/GitHub. This allows them to show commits in JIRA issues and also Smart Commits to transition issues based on commit messages. It would be great if it could link JIRA issues to Bitbucket/GitHub issues as well.

h3. Suggestion
Allow users to link JIRA issues to Bitbucket/GitHub issues

Additionally, create a synchronization between these issues such that
* When an issue is created in github, a corresponding issue would be created in jira
* Any new comments in the github issue would propagate to the jira ticket
* Any new comments in the jira ticket would propagate to the github issue
* If the github issue was closed, the linked jira ticket would be closed
* If the jira ticket was closed, the linked github issue would be closed.
fields.summary: Link JIRA issues to DVCS issues

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The workflow properly for {{jira.issue.editable = false}} are not behaving consistenly

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Configure the following workflow properties in the closed/done issue transition

{{jira.issue.editable = true & jira.permission.edit.group = jira-administrators}}
Only JIRA admins are able to edit closed issues
Project admins are not able to release kanbans

h3. Expected Result:
{{jira.issue.editable = true & jira.permission.edit.group = jira-administrators}}
Only JIRA admins are able to edit closed issues
Project admins are able to release kanbans

 
h3. Notes

*Situation 1*
{{jira.issue.editable = false}}
No one is able to edit closed issues
Project admins are able to release kanbans

*Situation 2*
{{jira.issue.editable = true & jira.permission.edit.group = jira-administrators}}
Only JIRA admins are able to edit closed issues
Project admins are not able to release kanbans
"You do not have permission to edit issues in this project"
 !Selection_110.png|thumbnail! 

*Situation 3*
{{jira.issue.editable = true & jira.permission.edit.group = jira-administrators & jira.permisson.edit.role = Project Admin}}
JIRA admins & project admins are able to edit closed issues
Project admins are able to release kanbans

Above testing shows a contradicting behavior of the properties when {{jira.issue.editable = true}} is used. The Project Admins are unable to release the Kanban when this property is used

Because supposedly, if in Situation 2, where Project Admins are unable to release Kanban, Project Admins should not be able to release Kanban in Situation 1 as well (as no one should be allowed to edit the closed issue) 


h3.Workaround
none
fields.summary: Editable Workflow Property does not behave as intended in releasing Kanban

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When importing a project into JIRA, it will generate rank values for each issue imported. While a Rank field is being re-balance, ranking of new issues will be heavily delayed.

h3. Expected Behavior
Re-balancing should introduce minimal overhead in JIRA's operations, including initially ranking imported or new issues and also performing other ranking operations.

h3. Actual Behavior
At the time of generating rank values for the newly-imported issues (see log entries below), there is a big difference in the time for each rank value to be generated.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have an instance of JIRA with a considerable amount of issues. Our testing environment had more than 500.000;
# Trigger the re-balance of an Agile LexoRank field;
# Perform a project import;

h3. Workaround
Even though a rebalance will not prevent the project from being imported, it will delay the process heavily. The only known way to perform the import in a faster pace is to wait for the re-balance to complete before importing projects.
fields.summary: Project Import heavily delayed when LexoRank re-balance is running

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm trying to help an organization install and configure the JIRA GitHub plugin.  We ran into this problem:

{quote}
Whenever I try to set up a repository, I keep getting an error about
"XSRF Security Token Missing".  I have tried numerous times, and it
consistently fails for me.

The error page recommends I look at
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-20696 which I did.  But the
description does not seem to fit.  This is definitely not a time out
issue as I have even logged out, logged back in and immediately tried
to set this up.
{quote}

There is also a reoccurring stack trace in the logs that mentions fisheye, but I don't think that's related.  

Have you seen this before or do you have any ideas?  I'm not sure if I should talk to you as the developer of the plugin or perhaps some of the JIRA devs. 

Thanks,
Charles

fields.description:
This Atlassian Answers entry describes my problem:

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/271053/problems-in-integrating-jira-and-github-using-dvcs-plugin

And this tidbit from Atlassian documentation seems to confirm:

The authorizing account is not necessarily the account that created the key and secret.  The authorizing account should have administrative access on all the repositories to be linked. 

This suggests that in order to link accounts using the DVCS Connector, as a JIRA admin, I also need to have admin rights to the (in this case) GitHub Enterprise repo? If the owner of the repo generates the client id and secret, isn't that supposed to give the DVCS connector the privileges it needs? I was assuming that the "team or user" account is the one that provides the client id and secret. Why does the linking process seem to want to use my GHE account privileges?

fields.description:
I have configured GHE with an application called 'JIRA', and home page and callback URLs both equal to 'https://atlassian.foo.net:8080/' (Name changed to protect the innocent).  In JIRA in the Add-ons manager, for DVCS Accounts, I click 'Link Bitbucket or GitHub account', enter our GHE URL (https://foogithub.foo.net) and the appropriate credentials. I click 'Add', then 'Continue', then I am sent to a really strange URL:

http://atlassian.slc.foo.net:8080/?error=redirect_uri_mismatch&error
_description=The+redirect_uri+MUST+match+the+registered+callback+URL+for+this+application.&error_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fdeveloper.github.com%2Fv3%2Foauth%2F%23redirect-uri-mismatch

Notice two things about the URL:

1) It's http (not https, as is the URL I entered in GitHub Enterprise)
2) The hostname is also different

If I change the 'http' to 'https' in the browser bar, I get an SSL security warning (as one would expect).

I suspect something is misconfigured in JIRA that it is redirecting to this (broken) URL... but what? Where can I configure that?
fields.summary: JIRA responding with unusual URL for GHE OAuth requests

fields.description:
Hi,

I followed these direction to setup DVCS Connector between our JIRA Cloud and BitBucket Cloud accounts:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/getting-started-with-bitbucket-and-jira-cloud-692420669.html#notfound

And it appears to be working, but the uptake and processing of smart commit messages takes a very long time. The last one I tried took 38 minutes to show, and I believe I am still waiting longer for my latest test.

I googled around and found this issue with a quote from Megan Cook that reads:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/DCON-379
"If you have webhooks installed, then you should see updates coming through within minutes of the action taking place in GitHub. The periodic syncing that the DVCS Connector does is just a backup measure incase the webhooks fail. If you're seeing updates take longer, please raise a support ticket so we can help troubleshoot your instance."

I checked the BitBucket repository webhooks screen for my repositories and I do not see any webhooks listed, so I think I must be in the same boat as the original reporter of DCON-379. 

Can you advise me on what steps I can take to ensure that smart commit messages are picked up and processed more quickly? Is there any way I can populate the missing webhooks myself? Or should I hang on and stand by for a bug fix?

Love the product line. I just returned from Atlassian Summit 2015 and it was awesome. 

Thanks!
fields.summary: DVCS Connector doesn't appear to setup our webhooks at BitBucket

fields.description:
The Activity Stream in JIRA is at the moment showing information regarding all commit messages.

Users without access to projects mentioned on the Commit Messages still see the messages and are provided links to pages were they don't have access to.

This is a Privacy concern on instances with Restricted Projects.
On instances with a lot of dev activity, this generates unnecessary noise on the Dashboard.

Activity Stream should be restricted to the user visibility according to permissions. Commits from issues without access should be discarded.
fields.summary: Activity Stream in JIRA for Bitbucket/Github commits should only show commits of relevant issues

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Steps to replicate:

# Add a new bitbucket account to your JIRA OnDemand instance via the DVCS connector.
# Click on the cog to the right of your new account and view 'configure automatic access'

Result:

Automatic access will be set up and membership to the 'developers' group will be granted

Expected result:

Either no automatic access will be set up, or during the creation process you should be warned that automatic access has been granted.

This is a security concern for users that add people that should have access to the repository to their OD account, as access will be granted unknowingly.

It also becomes more of a problem now that UNIFIED-79 has been released, as it's not at all obvious that membership is granted anymore.
fields.summary: Automatic access added to newly added bitbucket account without notificiation

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
From an admin point of view, it would be convenient to be able to estimate how long the initial sync will take for a given repo; that way, when we're adding a repo for the first time, we can tell our customers how long it might take for JIRA to catch up to Github.

In the absence of that information, our users tend to assume that it's nearly instant.
fields.summary: Calculate or forecast amount of time for repo to be fully sync'd

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Most of the tables in this plugin do not have proper indices. This causes  queries on large tables to be slow. Sometimes that slowness causes the DVCS Connector to stop working and affects DCON-338.

We want to add indices to the tables, based on the usage patterns in the code.
fields.summary: Add indexes to tables

fields.description:
GreenHopper's detail view doesn't cope well displaying the list of files changed within the smaller screen real estate. 

The file names are often too long to be displayed in the space available. Perhaps there is more useful information we could be displaying in this space.

This was raised as a comment on the pull request here:
https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/jira-bitbucket-connector/pull-request/68/greenhopper-detail-view-tab-for-commits/diff#comment-76517
fields.summary: Determine better display mechanism for changed files in a commit in GreenHopper

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: With linked Bitbucket or Github repositories the users in the commit messages are not able to be associated with Jira users.  To Jira its like two separate users, even though they are using the same email address.
fields.summary: Link Bitbucket and Github users to Jira users

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I don't know if this is currently possible; if so, please tell me how to do it.

We'd like to be able to search within JIRA for specific commits by the commit hash, so that we can see which issues were affected by a given code commit.
fields.summary: Ability to search using Github commit hashes

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When smart commits are enabled and new repository is configured such as during an import, all the previous commands are processes resulting in double entries.

Suggestion: only process smart commits for commits that occur after the discovery of the new repository.
fields.summary: Do not process smart commit commands for historical commits when hooking up a new repository

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: When performing a force synchronization, the plugin appears to be crawling the entire commit history for each branch it encounters. This seems unnecessary and could cause excessive calls to the API as well as remote disconnects/timeouts. It should be smarter about when it encounters parents it has already cached and not run duplicate change history.
fields.summary: When (force) synchronizing, don't crawl/cache duplicate commits from branches

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
At the moment, when there are commits from more than one repo for a single issue, the {{Commits}} tab does not show the source repository.

!dvcs.png!

Since that is the case, it is very difficult to identify which commits come from which repo.  The only way to confirm where the commit is from is by hovering the mouse over the full-commit button and examine the url. 

It would be convenient to organize the list of commits by the repository name, or mention the repository name.

----
The issue is even more pronounced when developer's public personal repos are being watched. Then you will have identical commits (that were accepted from the developer's repo into the mainline) showing up; For such cases, it would be great if Jira allowed filtering of identical commits by specifying an authorative repo to be shown first or exclusively.
fields.summary: Organize the Commits tab by listing the commits according to its repository

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
From an admin perspective, it'd be nice to be able to collapse or expand the repositories list on the DVCS account page. With large repos, it can get a bit scrolly.

This would also make it easier to vet the list of organizations/repos to make sure all of the appropriate ones have been added.
fields.summary: Collapse or expand feature on DVCS account admin page

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
It would be nice if we could use the ssh keys that we created in "Shared credentials" in Bamboo instead of having to supply a GitHub username and password.

It's not safe nor convenient for me to save my GitHub user id and password on Bamboo on-demand.  What would be better is if I generated ssh keys and register the public key on GitHub while the public key is stored in in Bamboo on-demand.
fields.summary: Support ssh keys when accessing GitHub via Bamboo
